pages.title: Welcome to lesson T1.
pages.text:
In the T series of lessons, we will be learning to touch-type on the standard
keyboard.  I will introduce you to each letter on the keyboard, one at a time.
By the time you have completed this series, you will be able to type the entire
alphabet, the numbers, and most of the punctuation keys by touch.
If you have never taken any lessons in typing before, please be patient.  Typing
is not difficult but it does take a lot of practice.  Avoid the tendency to
look down at your fingers while typing.  This is a very bad habit and is hard
to break later.  If you hit the wrong key, I will let you know.  (But, I won't
tell anyone else, so don't worry about it.)
If you have always used the hunt-and-peck method, you will have an even harder
time keeping yourself from looking.  Don't be surprised if you find touch
typing slower than your old ways.  It may be slower when you first start.
But, touch typing is far faster once you get the hang of it.
If you can already touch type, you should be able to go through these lessons
fairly quickly.  Or, you may want to go directly to the S series.

pages.title: The HOME Keys.
pages.text:
In order to hit the correct keys by touch alone, you must always know where your
fingers are.  The way to do this is to have a special place for each finger.
This key is called the HOME position.
Place the first finger of your right hand on the J-key.  Now, place your second
finger on the K-key, your third finger on the L-key, and your fourth-finger on
the ;-key (the one with the : and ; on it).
Similarly place the four fingers of your left hand on the F, D, S, and A-keys.
Place your right thumb over the SPACE bar.  (Henceforth, always hit the SPACE
bar with this thumb.)  Now, lift all your fingers slightly so that they are
poised just over the keys.  Each finger should be just barely touching its home
key.  This is an electronic keyboard and does not take much pressure to ac-
cidentally press the key down.
Learn these positions well.  Whenever you are about to type a line, look at your
fingers and make sure they are in the HOME position.  Then don't look at them
again.

pages.title: DRILL PATTERNS
pages.text:
For the rest of this lesson, I will display a line of text in the middle of the
screen and instructions at the top of the screen.
All you have to do is type in the characters that you see in the middle of
the screen.  If you hit the correct key, I will not do anything.  If you make
a mistake, I will display a large X under the letter that you got wrong and 
beep the terminal. In either event, just keep going by typing the next letter.
When you have finished typing the line, hit the RETURN key.  To do this, extend
the little finger of your right hand over to the RETURN key.  Hit the key and
zip the finger back to its home position.  Be careful not to let your other
fingers move far from their home positions in the process.  Also, be careful
not to type an extra space at the end of the line.
If you made no mistakes on the line, I will display the next drill pattern.  If
you did make a mistake, I will beep at you and make you do the line again.  If
on the second try you made more than two mistakes, I will beep again and make
you try again, etc.  Don't forget to use your right thumb for the SPACE bar.

pages.prompt: Hit the F-key four times with the first finger of your left hand.
lines: ffff

pages.prompt: Alternately, hit the F-key and the SPACE bar.
lines: fff fff fff ff ff ff f f f

pages.prompt: Don't look at your hands!
lines: jjj jjj jjj jj jj jj j j j

pages.prompt: Use the left hand for the F and the right hand for the J.
lines: fff jjj fff jj ff jj f j f j

pages.prompt: Now intermix them.
lines: ffjj jjff fjf fjf jfj jfj

pages.prompt: Use the second finger of the left hand for the D-key.
lines: ddd ddd ddd dd dd dd d d d

pages.prompt: Use the second finger of the right hand for the K-key.
lines: kkk kkk kkk kk kk kk k k k

pages.prompt: Now both.
lines: ddd kkk dd kk dkd kdk ddd kkk

pages.prompt: Use the third fingers of the each hand for the S and L-keys.
lines: sss lll sss lll sss ss ll ss ll s l

pages.prompt: Use the fourth fingers for the A and ;-keys.
lines: aaa ;;; aaa ;;; aa ;; aa ;; a ;

pages.prompt: That's enough keys for today.  Let's review them.
lines: fff jjj ddd kkk sss lll aaa ;;;

pages.prompt: Again.
lines: fff jjj ddd kkk sss lll aaa ;;;

pages.prompt: Try mixing them together.
lines: asdf jkl; asdf jkl; asdf jkl;

pages.prompt: And still more.
lines: fjf kdk sls ;a;

pages.prompt: Before, we finish, let's try some words.
lines: sad add all; alas flask fad

pages.prompt: How about a sentence.
lines: ask a sad lad

pages.prompt: Sentences are kind of limited with only one vowel!
lines: dad asks a lad; a lass falls

pages.title: In this lesson, we will review the letters that you have already practiced
pages.text:
and will add the letters E, G, and H and the period.
When you reach for any of these keys, be sure to return your finger to its
home position.  For example, to hit the H-key, move the first finger of your
right hand (the J-finger) slightly to the left.  Tap the H-key and immediately
bring your finger back over the J.
If you lose track of where your fingers are guess.  Don't look!

pages.prompt: First let's review
lines: fff jjj ddd kkk sss lll aaa ;;;

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the H key.
lines: jjj jhj jjj jhj jjj jhj

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the G-key.
lines: fff fgf fff fgf fff fgf

pages.prompt: Use your D-finger for the E-key
lines: ddd ded ddd ded ddd ded ddd

pages.prompt: Use your K-finger for the comma.
lines: kkk k,k kkk k,k kkk k,k

pages.prompt: Let's finish with some sentences.
lines: a lad had a flask, dad had a keg

pages.prompt: Let's review first.
lines: fff jjj ddd kkk sss lll aaa ;;;

pages.prompt: Use your K-finger for the I key.
lines: kkk kik kkk kik kkk iii kkk

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the R key.
lines: fff frf fff frf fff frf

pages.prompt: Use your L-finger for the period.
lines: lll l.l lll l.l lll l.l lll

pages.title: The next key we are going to practice is the right shift key.

pages.prompt: Don't look at your fingers!
Let's try some (strange) sentences.
lines: Sir, idle disks seek flags.

pages.prompt: Always double space after a period.
lines: A free red jade is fake.  Girls like silk.

pages.prompt: First a quick review:
lines: jkl; fdsa ded fgf jhj k,k kik frf l.l

pages.prompt: Use your L-finger for the O-key.
lines: lll lol lll ooo lll lol

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the P-key.
Try capitalizing each of the keys on the right-side:
lines: Joe Kip Leif Peg Olaf Ira Heidi

pages.prompt: Don't forget to use your right-shift key for letters on the left side:
lines: a;a P.S. a;a I.R.S. a;a

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the ?-key.
Let's try some sentences.
lines: Dad fell off a ladder.  Is he safe?

pages.prompt: Always double space after a question mark.
lines: Is he here?  Sal said he fell hard.

pages.prompt: As always, let's start with a review:
lines: ade fgh ijk lop rs; ?.,

pages.prompt: Again.
lines: ade fgh ijk lop rs; ?.,

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the T-key.
lines: fff ftf fff ttt fff ftf fff

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the N-key.
lines: jjj jnj jjj nnn jjj jnj jjj

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the :-key.
Always double space after a colon.
lines: Dear Sirs:  Dear John:  Dear Alfred:

pages.prompt: Let's review the letters we've already learned.
lines: jkj fdf jlj fsf j;j faf kik ded frf

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the B-key.
lines: fff fbf fff bbb fff fbf fff

pages.prompt: The B-key is the longest reach we've seen so far.  Let's try it again.
lines: fff fbf fff bbb fff fbf fff

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the U-key.
lines: jjj juj jjj uuu jjj juj jjj

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the /-key.
Try your speed on some paragraphs:
lines: ;/; n/a ;/; and/or ;/; left/right
In this era of E.R.A., I hope he/she likes his/her job.
He/she should bring his/her spouse at about noon or just before.
Should I be here alone?  Is Bernie and/or Julie going to be here, too?
there is no fee to be paid, return the
bill and put n/a in the total due part.

pages.prompt: First a review of the letters we've learned before:
lines: juj ded kik frf lol fgf ;p; jhj

pages.prompt: Use your D-finger for the C-key.
lines: ddd dcd ddd ccc ddd dcd

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the M-key
lines: jjj jmj jjj mmm jjj jmj jjj

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the hyphen.
Let's try some sentences:
lines: Peter Piper picked a peck of pickled peppers.

pages.prompt: There are three uses of the hyphen.  It can be used to combine two words:
lines: She had on a bluish-green dress.  But, no one noticed.

pages.prompt: To divide a word:
lines: At macrame class last night, I made a hanging basket for the philo-
dendron in our dining room.

pages.prompt: Or, to form a dash:
lines: Fifteen dollars a month--measured in current dollars--is a good rate.

pages.prompt: As always, we will start with a quick review
lines: jfj dkd lsl a;a dcd jmj ;-; fbf juj

pages.prompt: Let's try some long words.
lines: meteorology camera bituminous chimera phosphates

pages.prompt: Use your S-finger for the W-key.
lines: sss sws sss www sss sws sss

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the Y-key.
lines: jjj jyj jjj yyy jjj jyj jjj

pages.prompt: Try your speed on this sentence:
lines: jjj why jjj you jjj try jjj rye jjj
jjj year jjj July jjj your jjj jury jjj
Were your yard sales much better last year?

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the V-key.
lines: fff fvf fff vvv fff fvf fff

pages.prompt: First, a review.
lines: a;a sls dkd fjf sws jyj fvf dcd jmj ;-;

pages.prompt: Notice that the only letters left to go are the Q, X, and Z!
lines: abcdefghijklmnoprstuvwy

pages.prompt: Use your A-finger for the Q-key.
lines: aaa aqa aaa qqq aaa aqa aaa

pages.prompt: Use your S-finger for the X-key.
lines: sss sxs sss xxx sss sxs sss

pages.prompt: Use your A-finger for the Z-key.
lines: aaa aza aaa zzz aaa aza aaa
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

pages.prompt: Let's try some sentences:
lines: A dozen zebras were grazing quietly nearby.

pages.prompt: Let's try a sentence that contains every letter of the alphabet.
lines: A quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dogs.

pages.prompt: Again,
lines: A quick brown fox jumped over the lazy dogs.

pages.prompt: Let's review the entire alphabet before starting the number keys.
lines: abcd efg hijk lmnop qrs tuv wx yz

pages.prompt: Once more
lines: abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz

pages.prompt: Use the shift key for each letter (Do not use the CAPS LOCK key)
lines: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ

pages.prompt: Now, review the punctuations that you've had.

pages.title: NUMERIC KEYS
pages.text:
The terminal has two sets of numeric keys.  One set--directly above the
alphabetic keys--conforms to the standard for typewriter keyboards.  The other
set--to your right--resembles a calculator keypad.  In this typing series we
will be concerned only with the standard numeric keys on the main keyboard.
(If you would like to learn to touch type on a numeric keypad, use the N-series
lessons instead.)
NOTE - not all terminals have the numeric keys in a separate keypad
The numeric keys, like all the keys you will be learning from now on, vary
somewhat from machine to machine.  The 2 through 0 keys are always in exactly
the same place on all typewriter keyboards.  (On keypunch machines and some
terminals, however, they are located over the U, I, O, J, K, L, M, comma and
period keys.  We will not be concerned with these layouts in this series.)
Even if a typewriter or terminal has the standard 2 through 0 keys, it may not
have a 1 key.  If it does, the 1 will always be next to the 2.  If it does not,
you will have to use the L-key.

pages.prompt: Let's start by using the 1-key, since we have one.  (Use your A-finger.)
lines: aaa a1a aaa 111 aaa a1a

pages.prompt: Use your S-finger for the 2-key.
lines: sss s2s sss s2s sss s2s

pages.prompt: Use your D-finger for the 3-key.
lines: ddd d3d ddd d3d ddd d3d ddd

pages.prompt: The last number we will practice today is the 4-key.  (Use your F-finger.)
lines: fff f4f fff f4f fff f4f

pages.prompt: Try your speed on this line:
lines: fff f4r fff 4vr fff 4vr fff
444 for fff rat 444 vet 444
Flight 423 leaves from gate 42 at 4:24.
As the 3 musketeers say: 1 4 all, and all 4 1.
If 1/4 plus 2/3 is 11/12, what is 1/2 plus 1/3?

pages.prompt: As we stated earlier, many typewriters do not have a 1 key.  Let's practice
lines: One dozen is l2.  A gross is l2 dozen or l44.

pages.prompt: Let's review the numbers that you have already learned.
lines: a1a s2s d3d f4f 234 413

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the 7-key
lines: jjj j7j jjj j7j jjj j7j jjj

pages.prompt: Use your K-finger for the 8-key.
lines: kkk k8k kkk k8k kkk k8k kkk

pages.prompt: Use your L-finger for the 9-key.
lines: lll l9l lll l9l lll l9l lll

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the 0-key.
Let's try some paragraphs.
lines: Dear Sirs:  The 10:00 meeting on March 10 has been postponed until 10:30.
The 10:30 meeting was moved to 11:00 in Room 302.
But, Room 302 can only hold 10 people.  We will need Conference Room 10.
designate the regional office and the last 2
digits designate the local branch.  The numbering
is roughly east to west.  That is, numbers
starting with 0 are in New England, numbers
starting with 1 are the New York area, etc.
There are notable exceptions to this rule,
however.  The Virgin Islands are south of
Florida, but their Zip Codes start with 00.

pages.prompt: Let's review the numbers that you have learned so far.
lines: j7j f4f k8k d3d l9l s2s ;0; a1a

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the 5-key.
lines: fff f5f fff 555 fff f5f fff

pages.prompt: And now, the longest reach of all!  Use your J-finger for the 6-key.
lines: jjj j6j jjj 666 jjj j6j jjj

pages.prompt: The open parenthesis is the shift of the 9-key.  (Use your L-finger).
lines: j6j June j6j much j6j hum j6j
j6j y6n j6j u6m j6j h76 j6j

pages.prompt: The close parenthesis is the shift of the 0-key.  (Use your ;-finger).
Try your speed on this song.
lines: 4 little, 5 little, 6 little Indians,
7 little, 8 little, 9 little Indians,
10 little Indian boys.

pages.prompt: Use the main keyboard keys.  Don't cheat and use the auxilliary keypad!
Now let's try for some speed.

pages.title: There is no Lesson 13!  Don't you know that 13 is an unlucky number?
pages.text:
If you have completed Lessons T1 through T12, then you are now ready
to call yourself a touch typist.  You have learned to touch type all
of the keys which are standardized!  You can now begin the SPEED
series of lessons if you would like.  (If you come across a punctua-
tion symbol which you have not learned, simply look for it.  Use the
appropriate finger for the shifted numeric keys.  Use your ;-finger
for all the keys on the right-hand side.)
We will practice touch typing on the keyboard layout for the remaining
lessons.

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the apostrophe.
Shift the apostrophe for the quote key.
Use your A-finger for the exclamation point.
lines: aaa a!a aaa !!! aaa a!a aaa

pages.prompt: Always double space after an exclamation point.
lines: Tomorrow's quiz!  What if we get caught?  We'll be expelled!

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the equals key.
Use your K-finger for the asterisk key.
lines: kkk k*k kkk k*k kkk k*k kkk

pages.prompt: Use your ;-finger for the plus sign.
Use your L-finger for the greater-than key.
lines: lll l>l lll l>l lll l>l lll

pages.prompt: Use your K-finger for the less-than key.
lines: kkk k<k kkk k<k kkk k<k kkk

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the up-arrow key.
lines: jjj j^j jjj ^^^ jjj j^j jjj

pages.prompt: Try entering this BASIC program:
lines: j^j X^2 j^j Y^3 j^j Z^4 j^j
20 LET y=20
30 PRINT x+y/3
40 PRINT y/x*5
50 STOP

pages.title: In this lesson we will be practicing the shifted numeric keys on the
pages.text:
terminal keyboard.  I will only be giving you practice in the keystroke
motions.  Very few sentence drills or speed exercises are included, since these
keys are used so infrequently.
If you are typing something which includes one of these special characters and
you cannot remember where a key is, look.  But, always make sure to hit the key
with the correct finger.  (If you do use the key often, you will eventually
learn where it is without looking.)  Since these keys are used infrequently and
are in different places on most other keyboards or are totally missing, speed
is not important.

pages.prompt: Use your S-finger for the at-sign.
lines: sss s@s sss s@s sss s@s sss

pages.prompt: Use your D-finger for the pound-sign (also called the number-sign).
lines: ddd d#d ddd d#d ddd d#d ddd

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the dollar-sign.
lines: fff f$f fff f$f fff f$f fff

pages.prompt: Use your F-finger for the percent sign as well.
lines: fff f%f fff f%f fff f%f fff

pages.prompt: Use your J-finger for the ampersand.
lines: jjj j&j jjj j&j jjj j&j jjj
